Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of an Environmental Scanning Electron Microscope to Enable Cross-Disciplinary Research and Education
Award.AbstractNarration:
Researchers in several colleges at the University of California, Davis use an environmental scanning electron microscope to visualize and study changes in materials with time, from nanometer to the size of a whole device or system. The measurements are carried out in the working environment of materials, e.g., from water vapor to controlled type and pressure of gases. The microscopy is located at a broadly shared facility in the materials science department on the UC Davis main campus, serving users from campus, the medical center, local community colleges, industry and with high-school teachers and students in the Central Valley, California. The team uses a general theme of "Seeing in Science" to attract and increase participation from underrepresented minority students on and off campus. The environmental scanning electron microscope allows the team to demonstrate imaging of various samples on multiple length-scales at or close to their native environments with minimal need of prior sample treatment and preparation.

Acquisition of an environmental scanning electron microscopy, with a small modification by the principal investigators, enables in-situ characterization of materials and complex systems under high temperatures, applied mechanical stress, and controlled atmospheres. Operation under appropriate gas or vapor environments up to 4000 Pascals makes it possible to image insulating, electron beam-sensitive and hydrated materials and systems, such as ceramics, polymers and plant tissue. Research conducted using this microscope advances our fundamental scientific knowledge in interdisciplinary research topics, including the agglomeration kinetics of thin metal films, ceramics microstructure evolution during nanoscale processing, 3-dimensional assembly of nanostructures, fracture mechanics of bone, plant-microbe interaction for food safety, structure-functionality relationships of ocular lenses, and failure mechanisms of high-powered electronics. During the course of investigation, the researchers also identify approaches to enable data correlation between different imaging modes, disciplines, and data sources. Correlative characterization makes it possible to achieve structure-morphology-functionality relationships in entire device structures and whole organisms.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This Major Research Instrumentation (NSF-MRI) award was used to acquire an Environmental Scanning Electron Microscope (ESEM) that now provides rather unique experimental capabilities at the University of California, Davis. The instrument enables a variety of interdisciplinary research projects ranging from materials sciences, physics, chemistry, environmental & agricultural sciences, biological sciences, as well as medical and veterinary medical sciences. The ESEM enables microscopic imaging of samples with nanometer resolution, while simultaneously exposing inorganic materials as well as biological organisms to pressures as high as 3,000Pa. The latter facilitates the nanoscale imaging of living organisms. Additional capabilities include in-situ mechanical testing as well heating during imaging to temperatures as high as 1,400C.

The ESEM instrument was installed at the Advanced Materials Characterization and Testing Laboratory (AMCaT) at the University of California, Davis. The continuously increasing user base currently includes 85 graduate and undergraduate students each with unique research projects. The users come from 44 different research groups that span over 21 departments amongst 6 academic colleges at UC Davis. Research projects range from the development of novel nanogranular ceramics, tip-guided growth of arbitrarily shaped nanostructures, wetting-dewetting transitions at metal/semiconductor interfaces, the development of high-power electronics, mechanical analysis of plant-microbe interactions, nanoscale assembles during human digestion, the reconstruction of tissue architectures, mechanical deformation of bone, bone engineering, aggregation of food colloids, and others. The user base at UC Davis and from surrounding areas is highly interdisciplinary. In addition, the ESEM instrument impacts high school education in local school districts by its ability to visualize scientific concepts and nanostructures that most pupils have not seen before. This approach promises to have impact on the recruitment of high school students for degree programs in the STEM disciplines, and especially members from traditionally underrepresented student populations are targeted by mentoring activities.
